thread.title: Counter-terrorism measures missing more than a year after Curtis Cheng shooting
thread.title_full: Counter-terrorism measures missing more than a year after Curtis Cheng shooting

author: Rachel Olding
title: Counter-terrorism measures missing more than a year after Curtis Cheng shooting
text:
Silma Ihram said preventative measures had been slower to implement than law enforcement responses. Photo: Angela Wylie 
Some initiatives are not up and running after 16 months. 
Silma Ihram, a Muslim educator who was consulted as part of the 2015 response, said she was alarmed that law enforcement measures, such as tougher parole laws and criminal punishment, seem to have been implemented much faster than measures to help the community. Advertisement 
"The Muslim community is aware of many initiatives that need to be put in place that we have the skills and expertise to put in place but we are resource poor," she said. 
"We're surprised that, considering the amount of government resources being allocated to counter-terrorism that the preventative strategies have not been supported anywhere near as much as they should have been." 
However, academic Clarke Jones, a member of the Premier's Countering Violent Extremism Council established in 2015, said he was confident that the time taken to set up the advice line was necessary. 
"There is a lot of consultation going on, it's not a straightforward process," he said. "We've got to be careful that any strategy has buy-in by the communities and that's a very difficult process because there's not a lot of trust in government." 
He assessed the NSW government's approach to counter-terrorism as "very positive" and said it was taking time to build relationships. 
Measures that have been implemented include $4 million in grants for grassroots programs, the specialist school support teams and a Community Cohesion Ambassadors' Program with the Sydney Thunder cricket team as ambassadors. 
However, training to upskill school counsellors has been done using existing resources and budget, government records show . 
"This early development work has included mapping of relevant services and further analysis will occur for the frontline worker training program," newly-appointed Minister for Counter Terrorism, David Elliott, said on Sunday. 
"The phone service is in the final stages of development with community stakeholders." 
Labor MP and shadow attorney-general Paul Lynch said the government "seem to enjoy making media headlines around these serious issues but don't seem capable of delivery". 
"The government's rhetoric on counter-terrorism is enormous," he said. "Their actual performance is very ordinary." Advertisement
